awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project - Collaborative Methods for Addressing Student Success in Totality (CMAST III)
awd_abstract_narration:
Implementation Projects provide support to Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to design, implement, study, and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthen education and research. The project at Grambling State University seeks to build on previous successful efforts to increase participation of African-American students in STEM disciplines.  The goal of the project is to implement a holistic approach to STEM education that will impact the retention and graduation rates of STEM undergraduate students, particularly in critical fields of mathematics, physics, and data analytics. The project will impact all STEM majors at the institution, but it directly supports forty-five students annually as researchers, peer tutors or academic coaches.

The project has the objectives to: implement a big data training program to support the expansion of the education STEM students receive in data analytics; restructure the mathematics and physics curriculum; enhance the soft skills of STEM students, such as resume writing, preparing for interviews, and communications skills; and implement a research study that examines the interventions and develops a model that can be replicated by other institutions. Each objective is supported by a set of evidence-based strategies and activities, some of which will be studied for effectiveness in the setting of this university. The project will be advised and evaluated for effectiveness by internal and external advisory boards and by an evaluator.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The CMAST program at Grambling State University aimed to enhance the Mathematics, Physics, and STEM majors by increasing enrollment, retention, and graduation rates. While the program exhibited notable successes in certain areas, it also encountered challenges that require further attention.

One of the program's significant accomplishments was the increase in STEM graduates, surpassing the established target. This outcome is attributed to various factors, including enhanced student engagement through research opportunities, academic scholarships, and targeted support services. The program's emphasis on providing students with hands-on experiences, such as research projects and internships, has proven to be instrumental in their academic and professional development.

Furthermore, CMAST's recruitment efforts have yielded impressive results. The implementation of summer camps, workshops, and outreach initiatives has attracted a substantial number of students to the programs. These activities have been crucial in raising awareness about the importance of STEM education and creating a pipeline of qualified students for the university.

Despite these successes, the program encountered challenges in meeting retention goals for Mathematics and Physics majors. While there was an overall increase in retention rates, the program fell short of its specific targets for some disciplines. Factors such as the COVID-19 pandemic, which disrupted academic continuity, may have contributed to these challenges.

To address these issues, the program should prioritize targeted interventions to support Mathematics and Physics students. This could involve providing additional academic support services, mentoring programs, and career counseling. Moreover, exploring innovative teaching methods and curriculum enhancements can help to increase student engagement and retention in these fields.

The program's evaluation also highlighted the importance of continuous assessment and data analysis to inform decision-making. By tracking student outcomes and identifying areas of strength and weakness, CMAST refined its strategies and allocated resources effectively. Additionally, fostering strong collaborations with industry partners provided students with valuable practical experience and increased employment opportunities upon graduation.

In conclusion, the CMAST program has demonstrated significant progress in enhancing STEM education at Grambling State University. While challenges persist, the program's successes in increasing graduation rates and attracting students to STEM fields provide a solid foundation for future growth. By addressing the identified areas for improvement and maintaining a focus on student success, CMAST can continue to make a positive impact on the university and the community.

 


Last Modified: 09/10/2024
Modified by: Naidu V Seetala
